_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing
All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
5/31/2013

                Executive Summary

     Agrium, North Bend Nitrogen - North Bend, OH



A.   Introduction:



This facility produces a variety of agricultural fertilizers as well as industrial chemicals.  Agrium North Bend Nitrogen Operations (NNO) produces nitric acid, ammonium nitrate solution, aqua ammonia solution, and UAN solution.  Additionally, NNO ships anhydrous ammonia without being processed.  



Ammonia is the precursor chemical for most of the processes that take place on site.  Anhydrous ammonia is brought to the site either via rail or by barge and stored in an atmospheric pressure tank.  The ammonia is vaporized and oxidized over precious metals gauze at high temperatures and pressure.  This creates NOx gas that is then absorbed into water in two absorbing towers acting in succession.  The NOx absorbed into the water creates nitric acid.  The nitric acid is sold out of the facility in a number of different grades depending on customer specifications.  



Some of the nitric acid is used in making ammonium nitrate (AN) solution.  This process mixed nitric acid with anhydrous ammonia vapor in the Neutralizer and the reaction forms AN solution.  This solution is mainly sold for further refining, by other companies, into explosives.  



Aqua ammonia (aqua) is made by absorbing anhydrous ammonia into water.  This aqua is used in many different applications.

NNO also produces urea ammonium nitrate (UAN) solution.  This solution is manufactured by dissolving granular urea and granular AN into a solution for use as a fertilizer. The facility also has the capabilities to receive UAN via barge. Upon receipt of this product, it is then diluted down with water to lower concentrated product. Some of the AN solution produced at the site is used in the manufacture of the UAN.



B.  Accidental Release Prevention and Record:



NNO has an excellent safety record with no deaths or serious injuries to plant personnel or contractors since it was construct

ed in 1965.  In addition, the plant has operated without a lost time accident for over 3 years, and has operated well over 230,000 man-hours. There has been one RMP reportable release of toxic chemicals in the last 5 years.



* In case of a reportable chemical accident, information in the RMP will be updated within six (6) months of the date accident occurred.



C. Accidental Release Prevention Policies and Program:



As part of the management system for Process Safety Management, a plant wide computer system is utilized which incorporates maintenance and process safety. Computers located in strategic locations are used to access plant files for P&ID drawings, operating procedures, Management of Change (MOC) documents, and other pertinent documents.  This system is used to provide our employees with the necessary tools and records for process safety requirements.  It plays an integral part in the safety efforts of this plant. In addition, plant personnel and full time contractor personnel routinely participate in monthly safety meetings.



NNO believes safety and protection of the environment must be second nature to all employees and full time contractor personnel.



Each plant employee and permanent contractor is trained to be familiar with the Emergency Response policies and procedures through safety reviews and plant safety meetings. The Emergency Response Plan is reviewed on an annual basis as part of the employee and full time contractor safety meetings to ensure refresher training.  The corporate environmental policy is also reviewed yearly.



NNO requires the Emergency Response Plan be followed in the event of an emergency. The emergency alarm system is tested twice each month and an emergency drill is held four times a year.



Local LEPC and Miami Township Fire Department personnel are furnished a copy of the Emergency Response Plan each time it is revised.  In addition, they are furnished copies of the Tier II document showing the chemicals stored o

n site, location, and quantities stored.



NNO personnel participate in local emergency drills conducted by the Hamilton County LEPC and the Miami Township Fire Department.



NNO participates in a local Community Advisory Panel composed of representatives from the plants on Brower Road, a group of community individuals including elected officials from the local communities, local school personnel, citizen representatives, and Miami Township Fire Department personnel.  NNO personnel also attend the Greater Cincinnati Alliance for Chemical Safety meetings held monthly.



General Accident Release Prevention Program Steps:



Accident release prevention steps include the fourteen elements OSHA's Process Safety Management program, an Emergency Management System (EMS), and corporate oversight of the facility.  



NNO management strongly encourages all employees to participate in all facets of process safety and accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation include updating and compiling technical documents, the availability of process safety information via networked computers to all employees, participation in Process Hazard Analyses, and periodic employee training.  NNO has an employee participation plan that documents many other ways employees are involved in accident prevention and process safety.



NNO has a comprehensive PSM program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this system, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.



NNO has well-established mechanical integrity practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, compressors, and emergency shutdown systems.



Training of plant personnel includes: (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plans, and (4) applicable safe work practices.

NNO has a comprehensive MOC system to manage changes to the processes.  This system requires that process changes be reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards.  The MOC system verifies that existing controls have not been compromised.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, equipment information, and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, all effected personnel receive training on the change.



D. Worst Case Scenario:



This information was removed from the executive summary in accordance with (40 CFR 68.190 (b) (6).



E.  Anhydrous Ammonia Alternative Scenario: 



Several alternative release scenarios were evaluated by NNO.  The most likely release scenario would involve a release of hot anhydrous ammonia from a pressure relief valve on the ammonia vaporizer bottle in the nitric acid plant.  This part of the process involves anhydrous ammonia under elevated temperatures and pressures.  This alternative scenario could result in offsite consequences.  As part of our PSM System, NNO has in place inspection and other measures intended to ensure the integrity of our process.  Specifically, the process equipment is inspected on a regular basis.



F.  Aqua Ammonia Alternative Release Scenario: 



Several possible aqua ammonia release scenarios were evaluated but the diked loading operation was selected as the scenario since it involves use of hoses and truck connections.  This alternative scenario could result in offsite consequences.



G.   Nitric Acid Alternative Release: 



This facility brings 98% concentrated nitric acid in by truck or rail cars.  The 98% acid is immediately diluted with product acid when unloaded to a maximum of 83-84%.  No acid is stored above 85% strength in any of the facilityA?s storage vessels.  The unloading operation was selected as the alternative scenario because this is the only time 85% or higher strength acid is in the plant.  Standard

unloading procedures and equipment checks are in place to reduce the possibility of an incident. This alternative scenario could result in offsite consequences.



H.   Five Year Accident History:



The Agrium North Bend Nitrogen Operation facility has not had an RMP reportable accident or an EPA reportable quantity release of aqua ammonia, or nitric acid in the last five years.  There has been one EPA RQ of anhydrous ammonia, but did not result in off-site consequences.  We believe the policies and programs in place at our facility will help us to maintain our exemplary record in future years.



I.   Emergency Response:



NNO works closely with the local fire departments and LEPC.   Personnel from the plant have participated in local emergency drills with the local fire departments, and the Hamilton County LEPC, Participation has occurred at both on site and at neighboring facilities.



The facility Emergency Action Plan (EAP) covers accidental releases of facility chemicals, natural disasters, emergency response practices and procedures, and process safety topics.  The plan is reviewed each year with all employees.



* Updates to the emergency contact information will be reported within one (1) month of change.



J.   Summary



The facility safety record is the direct result of a great deal of emphasis on safety on the part of plant management, corporate support, employees, contractors, and truck drivers. Agrium NNO is proud of its safety record and believes the policies and programs in place will ensure continued safety excellence.



Revised: 5/33/2013
